general: This law was passed in 2007 to help protect consumers when they buy goods or services. It sets up an organization called the National Consumer Council to handle complaints about things like faulty products or poor service. The law also requires some businesses to join "redress schemes" which helps consumers get their money back if something goes wrong. Additionally, the law makes it easier for people to cancel contracts they made outside of a store or office. Overall, the purpose of this law is to ensure that consumers are treated fairly and have a way to resolve disputes with businesses.

series.short: "Establishment of Local Consumer Committees for Better Representation"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The National Consumer Council and territorial committees are established to provide advice and information to the council about consumer matters affecting different areas of the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The territorial committees have the power to exercise certain functions on behalf of the National Consumer Council, including providing advice and information to the council about consumer matters affecting their respective areas.
* Simplified point 3: The National Consumer Council can impose restrictions or conditions on the exercise of functions by territorial committees, and can give them general or specific directions relating to the exercise of those functions.
* Simplified point 4: The territorial committees have the purpose of providing advice and information to the National Consumer Council about consumer matters affecting their respective areas, and such other purposes as the council may determine.

series.short: Consumer Matters: Definition and Coverage
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines the term "consumer" and explains how it applies to various situations.
* Simplified point 2: The definition of "consumer" includes anyone who purchases, uses, or receives goods or services in Great Britain, as well as those who use relevant postal services in Northern Ireland.
* Simplified point 3: The definition also covers future consumers and includes individuals who use services, such as addressees of relevant postal services.
* Simplified point 4: The section establishes that "consumer matters" refers to issues related to consumers' interests and anything connected to those interests.
* Simplified point 5: The term "designated consumers" refers to specific groups of consumers who are covered by this part of the act, including those who receive gas or electricity through pipes or distribution systems, and those who use relevant postal services.
* Simplified point 6: The Secretary of State has the power to add or remove descriptions of consumers from the list of designated consumers through an order, but must first consult with certain parties before doing so.

series.short: "Water Consumers' Needs Prioritized by Council"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Council for Water determines its priorities for the upcoming year based on the needs of designated consumers, including those with low incomes, disabled or chronically ill individuals, and those living in rural areas.
* Simplified point 2: The Council publishes a forward work program outlining its planned activities and estimates of expenditure for the year, including a statement of priorities and a general description of projects.
* Simplified point 3: The forward work program must be published annually and includes a notice specifying the period for making representations about the proposals contained in it.
* Simplified point 4: The Council must consider any representations received and amend its forward work program accordingly.
* Simplified point 5: The Council must exercise its functions in the most efficient and economic way possible and have regard to the need to use its resources in the most efficient and economic way.

series.short: "Council's Annual Report Requirements: Progress, Voluntary Activities, and Ministerial Submission."
series.text:
* The council must prepare an annual report at the end of every financial year detailing their activities during the year.
* The annual report must include information about the progress of projects in the forward work program, any voluntary activities done that year, and any other matters directed by the secretary of state.
* The council must send a copy of the annual report to the secretary of state, scottish ministers, and welsh ministers.
* The secretary of state must lay a copy of the annual report before parliament.
* The council must arrange for the annual report to be published.

series.short: "Empowering Consumers: Advice, Information, and Advocacy for Fair Markets"
series.text:
* The Consumer Council can provide advice and information to various entities such as government departments, regulatory bodies, and international organizations on consumer matters.
* The Council can also represent the views of consumers on these matters and keep information about consumer issues under review.
* The Council has the power to publish and distribute information to the public about consumer matters, and support other organizations that promote consumer interests.

series.short: "Consumer Protection and Investigation Powers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007 gives the Council the power to investigate complaints made by or on behalf of consumers regarding problems with goods or services provided by businesses.
* Simplified point 2: The Council may investigate complaints related to disconnections of gas or electricity, and provide advice or make representations on behalf of the consumer to the supplier.
* Simplified point 3: The Council may refuse to investigate a complaint if it appears to be frivolous or vexatious, or if there are other compelling reasons why it is inappropriate for the complaint to be investigated.
* Simplified point 4: The Council may refer complaints to the Gas and Electricity Markets Authority or the Postal Services Commission if they relate to matters within their jurisdiction.
* Simplified point 5: The Council may investigate matters relating to public post offices, including the number and location of such offices.

series.short: "Council's Reporting & Advisory Powers: Empowering Consumers Through Research & Cooperation"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumer Council can prepare reports related to consumer matters and publish them.
* Simplified point 2: The Secretary of State can request the Council to prepare reports on specific consumer matters and publish them.
* Simplified point 3: The Council can issue advice and guidance to improve standards of service and promote best practices for handling consumer complaints.
* Simplified point 4: The Council must enter into cooperation agreements with designated bodies like the Office of Fair Trading and the Financial Services Consumer Panel to share information and coordinate activities.
* Simplified point 5: The Council can make arrangements to cooperate with and assist any person if it will help exercise its functions.
* Simplified point 6: The Council can provide research and other services to anyone, charge fees for these services, and spend money on exploiting commercial opportunities.
* Simplified point 7: The Council can establish or acquire existing companies to exercise its functions, but only with the consent of the Secretary of State.

series.short: "Estate Agent Regulation: Consumer Protection and Enforcement Measures"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007 provides information regarding the powers of the Council when dealing with complaints against estate agents.
* Simplified point 2: The Council can request information from individuals or organizations, including their personal details, financial records, and other relevant data, to investigate and resolve consumer complaints.
* Simplified point 3: If the Council suspects that an estate agent has violated the law, they can issue a notice under Section 24 of the Act, requiring the agent to provide information or documentation to support their case. Failure to comply with this notice can result in legal action and fines.
* Simplified point 4: The Council can also publish information about estate agents who have failed to comply with the Act's requirements, including their names and the nature of their non-compliance. This serves as a deterrent to encourage compliance with the law.

series.short: "Consumer Protection Overhaul: New Council, Transfer of Functions, and Modification of Conditions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The act abolishes two consumer bodies named Energywatch and Postwatch. Their functions are transferred to the newly created National Consumer Council.
* Simplified point 2: The National Consumer Council takes over the functions of the Gas and Electricity Consumer Council and the Consumer Council for Postal Services.
* Simplified point 3: The act allows the Secretary of State to designate the Consumer Council for Water for abolition, and makes provision for transfer orders and abolition orders to be made in respect of it.
* Simplified point 4: Payment conditions may be made in respect of the expenses of the Council, the Secretary of State, or the Consumer Council for Water, and the Authority may modify these conditions as necessary.
* Simplified point 5: The act allows for the modification of other conditions included in appointments or licences related to water supplies, and directs the Authority to secure that sums relating to expenses are included in the payments.

series.short: "Government Compensation and Transfer Schemes for Consumer Councils Abolition"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The government can pay compensation to people who lose their jobs due to the abolition of certain consumer councils.
* Simplified point 2: The government can direct these councils to transfer their property, rights, and liabilities to the new council, and can also make schemes for the transfer of these things.
* Simplified point 3: The government can require these councils to provide information about their property, rights, and liabilities, and can also direct them not to take certain actions.

series.short: "UK Regulatory Reforms for Postal Services: Greater Consumer Protection and Efficient Governance"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can give more responsibilities to the Postal Services Commission (Council) if it's beneficial for consumers.
* Simplified point 2: The new responsibilities cannot conflict with the current ones, and the Council must consult before implementing any changes.
* Simplified point 3: The UK government can remove some of the Council's functions regarding Northern Ireland if there are alternative bodies that can perform those tasks effectively.

series.short: "Government Appoints Consumer Panel Members"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The government can direct the Financial Services Authority (FSA) and Ofcom (a communications regulator) to appoint members to consumer panels based on nominations from the National Consumer Council.
* Simplified point 2: These appointees must be non-executive members of the National Consumer Council and can only serve on one panel at a time. If they cease to be non-executive members, they will no longer be eligible to serve on the panel.

series.short: "Definitions and Expressions Used in Relation to Gas and Electricity"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines key terms used throughout the Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007. These include "distribution system," "financial year," "functions," "gas," "licensed water supplier," "modify," "postal services," and "regulatory body."
* Simplified point 2: The section also specifies that certain expressions used in relation to gas and electricity have the same meanings as in other acts, such as the Gas Act 1986 and the Electricity Act 1989.

series.short: Consumer Protection Act: Key Definitions and Regulatory Bodies
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines key terms used in the rest of the act related to consumers, estate agents, and redress. It explains that a "consumer" refers to anyone who purchases goods or services for personal use, rather than for resale or business use.
* Simplified point 2: The section also defines "regulated providers," which includes persons holding certain licenses under the Gas and Electricity Acts, water undertakers, and licensed water suppliers. These providers must comply with certain requirements and standards set out in the Act.
* Simplified point 3: The table in the section lists various types of regulated providers and their corresponding regulators. For example, a gas supplier is regulated by the Gas and Electricity Markets Authority, while an electricity supplier is regulated by the Postal Services Commission.
* Simplified point 4: The section also introduces the concept of "consumer complaints," which can be made against regulated providers by or on behalf of consumers. The complaints can relate to any aspect of the service provided by the regulated provider.
* Simplified point 5: Finally, the section sets out the jurisdiction of the regulators, stating that they have the power to investigate and resolve complaints made against their regulated providers.

series.short: "Consumer Complaint Handling Standards"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007 requires regulators to set standards for handling consumer complaints.
* Simplified point 2: These standards must be prescribed by regulations and may cover all consumer complaints or specific types of complaints.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations may specify standards for the handling of complaints based on the subject matter of the complaint or the type of person making the complaint.
* Simplified point 4: Before making regulations, regulators must conduct research and consult with various stakeholders to ensure that the standards are appropriate and enforceable.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations must be available to the public and may require regulated providers to supply information to consumers about the standards and their levels of compliance.

series.short: "UK Consumer Redress Scheme Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government requires certain businesses, such as energy and water providers, to offer a redress scheme for consumer complaints.
* Simplified point 2: The redress scheme must be approved by a relevant regulator, such as Ofgem or Ofwat, and must provide for an independent person to investigate and determine complaints.
* Simplified point 3: The regulator may require the scheme administrator to provide certain types of redress, such as compensation or apologies, to complainants.
* Simplified point 4: The regulator may also require the scheme administrator to provide information to the regulator and other bodies, such as the Office of Fair Trading.
* Simplified point 5: If the regulator refuses or withdraws its approval of a redress scheme, it must give notice to the scheme administrator and the Secretary of State.

series.short: Consumer Protection Law: Improved Complaint Handling Procedures
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows regulatory bodies to enforce certain requirements set forth in Part 2 of the act.
* Simplified point 2: These requirements include those related to complaint handling procedures for consumers dealing with estate agents, energy providers, postal services, and water supply companies.
* Simplified point 3: The law also expands the definition of "relevant requirements" in existing laws to include obligations imposed under sections 43, 46, and 47 of the act, which pertain to complaint handling procedures.
* Simplified point 4: The goal of these changes is to improve consumer protection and redress in various industries, particularly in relation to complaint handling processes.

series.short: "Estate Agent Regulation: Detailed Record-Keeping & Complaint Resolution"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007 requires estate agents to maintain detailed records of their transactions and dealings with clients for a minimum of six years.
* Simplified point 2: The Act also mandates that estate agents must join a redress scheme to handle customer complaints, and failure to do so can result in legal penalties.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation updates existing laws regarding estate agents' duties and adds new provisions related to keeping permanent records of client interactions and transactions.
* Simplified point 4: The Act empowers the Secretary of State to create regulations governing the storage and maintenance of these records, as well as the redress schemes themselves.

series.short: "Consumer Protection Measures for Estate Agents in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act 2007 aims to improve consumer protection in the UK by giving the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) more power to regulate estate agents.
* Simplified point 2: The OFT can now issue "prohibition orders" to estate agents who have been found to be unfit to carry out their work, or who have failed to comply with previous warnings or undertakings. These orders can prohibit the agent from carrying out certain activities or even from trading altogether.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also allows the OFT to issue "warning orders" to estate agents who have engaged in misleading or unfair practices, but who do not meet the criteria for a prohibition order. These orders require the agent to take specific steps to improve their practices or face further action.
* Simplified point 4: The changes to the Estate Agents Act 1979 introduced by this legislation aim to strengthen the OFT's ability to regulate the estate agency industry and protect consumers from unscrupulous practices.

series.short: "UK Consumer Protection Laws: Enhanced Enforcement Powers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has given enforcement authorities the power to investigate potential violations of consumer protection laws.
* Simplified point 2: Enforcement authorities have the power to enter and inspect premises where they suspect an offense has been committed or that someone has failed to comply with an obligation.
* Simplified point 3: If an individual fails to provide requested information, the court may order them to take action to remedy the situation.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation includes provisions for obstruction and personation of authorized officers, with penalties for failing to assist or provide information.

series.short: "Consumer Rights: Cancellation of Contracts Made Away from Business Premises"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act of 2007 allows consumers to cancel contracts made away from business premises.
* Simplified point 2: This law gives consumers the right to cancel contracts made with traders at their homes or workplaces, provided the contract was made during a solicited visit by the trader.
* Simplified point 3: The law also requires traders to inform consumers about their rights to cancel the contract and the effects of doing so.
* Simplified point 4: Orders and regulations made under this act must be made by statutory instrument, and any modifications to existing laws cannot be made without parliamentary approval.
* Simplified point 5: The law provides for incidental, supplementary, consequential, transitory, and transitional provisions and savings.
* Simplified point 6: Minor, consequential, and transitional provisions can be made through an order by the Secretary of State.
* Simplified point 7: Repeals and amendments are included in schedules 7 and 8 of the act.
* Simplified point 8: The act extends to England and Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, with some provisions extending only to certain regions.

summary: The Consumers, Estate Agents and Redress Act of 2007 is designed to protect consumers from unfair treatment by estate agents, energy providers, postal services, and water supply companies. The law creates redress schemes to handle consumer complaints and sets standards for complaint handling procedures. It also empowers regulatory bodies to enforce certain requirements set forth in Part 2 of the act, and updates existing laws regarding estate agents' duties. The law gives consumers the right to cancel contracts made with traders at their homes or workplaces, provided the contract was made during a solicited visit by the trader. Overall, the aim of the law is to improve consumer protection and redress in various industries, particularly in relation to complaint handling processes.
